snippet.title: Is Yellowstone's Train Station Based On a Real Place?
snippet.description:
Is the train station on Yellowstone real? Or is at least based on a real place? 

#yellowstone #yellowstoneseason4 #paramountnetwork 

Find Dutton Rules: A Yellowstone and 1883 Podcast
Apple: https://bit.ly/DuttonRules 
Spotify: https://spoti.fi/3BPkcug

0:00 | Is Yellowstone's train station real?
0:35 | Yellowstone characters who've gone to the train station
0:58 | History of the train station on Yellowstone
1:30 | The truth about the train station
2:25 | Why the Zone of Death exists? 
3:45 | The latest train station passenger

Vox's story - https://www.vox.com/2014/5/22/5738756/you-can-kill-someone-in-a-section-of-yellowstone-and-get-away-scot 

When you first start watching Yellowstone it seems mighty nice of men like Rip and Lloyd to offer to take fired employees to the train station. 

Throughout most of the first three seasons we only see the Dutton’s make that drive. We never really learn why they chose it. First it’s Fred, who is deposited as seen a few seconds ago. Then Walker, who strikes a deal with Kayce to live. He might be the only person to ever return. Then it’s referred to as the place to take Wade Marrow in Season 3 and he eventually his body gets dumped there, along with his son. 

It’s during that moment in Ep. 9 of Season 3, called “Meaner Than Evil,” that we learn the historical nature of the train station. Lloyd tells Walker that it’s a location used to dump bodies by all sorts of people because it’s in a lawless land. There are no residents and no cops. It’s 100 miles of human-less real estate so the bones just pile up. And, as it turns out, there is a nub of truth to this. The Train Station may very well be based on a real-life lawless land.
